headline: Fake it till you make it
pros:
Easy money if you have unlimited access to the Venture Capital money pot
HR no longer has limits for max % of increment. Everything lies in the hands of the line manager and the Budget.
So if we fake it enough, and communicate well, even a tech job with no tech knowledge gives you a promotion and big increments to the next grade. It helps if you’re female
If your boss favours you enough, they’ll be nice enough to reward you based on team effort (on the coat tails of the rest of the  teammates work) Even if you have just done just enough.
Nice remote work from different locations at co working allows me to run errands when I’m not busy
have a godfather and you’re all set for a bright future.
cons:
The chief person overall isn’t tech savvy enough to know he’s being promised big outcomes from startups which have yet to prove profitable. 

They lied abt why much increments barely given at Group level when it was freely given abundantly at ventures. Every recruiter knows this.

Zero increments in some India where more jobs than workers meant staff will resign. We’ve lost a lot of good talent

The pursuit of digitalisation and huge payouts has normalised underhanded practices such as harassment of approvers via personal mobile, WhatsApp late nights and 7am, harassment  by intimidation, backhanded remarks, name dropping of ceo as if they’re exempt from the code of conduct. 

Some ventures just want to get things done, so this means they are ruthless. You can be unwell and yet they will harass you.  If you skip meals and sleep to do them the favour, they’ll come back again to expect the same a few more times. Money is everything which means they’ll throw you under the bus anytime it profits them. Whatever religiousness, principles, empathy anyone has, all goes down the drain.

They dare do this because their founder has strings with the Chief C level person, so they have the confidence they will never get implicated 

Use and dispose culture.

headline: Many unaddressed issues
pros: I had an amazing job at SCB and worked with great people.
cons:
The workload is overwhelming and you are not given the resources to do your job. Pay is far below average and raises are very far between. There is a lot of consolidation of jobs, so you will be forced to do multiple roles without any additional support or compensation. This makes it interesting because you gain a lot of experience, but also there is no work life balance. It’s all work.

Promotions are difficult to receive. Many years in a row there were no promotions.

 The majority of the women in senior roles left the bank in 2021. They all left within a few months of each other. This speaks to the rampant sexism present at SCB. Mediocre males are promoted above talented women time and time again.

headline: Good place to work but excessive bureaucracy is a major hurdle
pros: Team members and colleagues are generally nice and helpful. Managers have good intentions but see comments in Cons below. Work hours are reasonable and hybrid working policies are good.
cons:
Very bureaucratic and people struggle to take decisions out of fear and too many things have to be escalated to the top. Decision making is concentrated in the hands of a few and slow. Too much time is spent navigating the bureaucracy and avoiding individuals who are always difficult. 

The organisation is diverse but not inclusive especially towards women and minority ethnicities. While managers are decent people, other teams like HR will inflict micro aggressions and use the bank’s bureaucracy to wear you down. After a while you realise these are not one-off incidents and you get demotivated. It is difficult to discuss these issues in the bank because managers don’t have a similar experience and things seem perfectly fine on the surface. But the micro-aggressions start to add up and opting out feels like the best option.

headline: Chill place to work but for same role & same job functions they pay differently, depending on Tier-I/II/III college
pros:
1. Pace of work is relatively relaxed
2. If you work on iOS app dev, you get a MacBook Pro
3. If you're a Woman then recently SCB is pushing more for female representation on top, so you can expect to get more attention from higher ups on your learning & career growth & promotions.
cons:
1. Their 6 weeks training program tries to teach you Front -end, backend & Database & JIRA; but it actually fails as you're taught everything for just 1 week & have to immediately switch to learning sth else immediately. And on top of that they expect you to implement these learnings & showcase in a project in those 6 weeks itself.
2. I'm from Tier -I college, & it's sad to see a very toxic hierarchy for salaries & promotions in place based on if you come from good college or not.
3. When you're allotted to a new team, it takes them 2-3 weeks to even fully provide you access to key software you need & there are just no mentors to guide & help you understanding the project you're working on.

headline: Working with Standard Chartered Bank
pros: Fantastic cultures structures in place to make employees comfortable, most importantly to ensure work-life balance. The bank takes personal development seriously and has a fairly good framework in place to support employees in this regard. Finally, work place health a safety is taken very seriously.
cons:
Too much power given to line management/business and HR has little or no influence on people welfare. All HR people policies and benefits are given at the discretion of the line management/business and consequently, the experience with different employees is not homogeneous across the bank. Until the bank addresses this structure, or better still, train managers on decision making when it comes to benefits, this will continue to be a pain and the will continue to lose goodwill. 

The bank itself has all the fantastic structures in place to be the best place in the world to work, but the people is the problem.

pros: Some great people, fair salaries, subsidised staff food

Needlessly difficult process to reset password, needlessly difficult process to get access, needlessly convoluted process to get access to production systems during critical incidents (try to raise an incident and then type in 5+ passwords to get a password?). IT management were clueless how releases work and line separating Dev and Support functions. Cronied up to next 3 levels of structure...and looking to "carve up". Outsourcing lead to all the offshore locations were too afraid to do their work and lost care

headline: Doing what they can with what they have.
pros: Individuals across the function seem mostly committed to doing the right things for the right reasons. However key failures in accountability and inability to remove underperformers leaves the organization bloated with non contributors, which creates drag on those who are trying to promote positive change.
cons: People in critical roles (project or initiative leads) tend to be glory hounds without real competency, resulting in lackluster outcomes and projects languishing without real direction or leadership. HR function fails dramatically to protect staff or to champion the staff, preferring to roll out feel good or half executed initiatives rather than do some real digging to identify problems in staff morale. Lack of accountability results in underperformers who can tai chi their responsibilities to survive very well.

headline: Great Bank but choose your Line Manager wisely
pros:
- Innovative Bank that strives to keep up with the technology
- Leaders try to foster a good working culture (i.e. a Bank that cares)
- flexible working and nice benefits
- volunteer opportunities
cons:
The bank may care but be aware that implementations of all Bank policies is left to the Line Managers’ discretion . 
If you have a bad manager, she / he can make life hell (e.g very political environment, no increment for successive years, refusal to keep up with times especially on flexible working etc) and there will be zero support .  
Unfortunately there is no review process for the effectiveness of a line manager (apart from the yearly employee assessment which brings no results).

As with all careers,  choose your line manager wisely as your career in the Bank is dependent on that!

cons: Salary in Bangalore,India is below average as per market standards that is the only cons. That’s why smart and highly skilled employees switch to different banks and get 100% hike, sometime even more. The reason because SCB India is already paying below average. So In order to meet the market standards salary company need to offer at-least 70% hike on current salary and hike of minimum 30% on the market standards salary is what most employee are looking. That’s why skilled people get 100% hike after switching from SCB India to different company.

headline: Why corporations get a bad name today
pros:
Global organization
Exposure
A few good people
Yearly bonus
cons:
Some managers do the bare minimum
Need to be with the "in" crowd to get real recognition
Titles are overly respected; people subconsciously discriminate based on your role and are conversely afraid to speak up against higher management
Colleagues use underhanded tactics that are not apparently visible; a "team" until it devolves into you vs me
Fake performance ratings; they are decided in advance, and meetings are held after the fact, especially if your team isn't big/the work they do is not seen as crucial.
Generation gap between some org leaders and new joiners
If you are good at kissing a**, this is the place for you

headline: DO NOT join the FCC- SPOT Team
pros:
Overall culture is good
Good learning opportunities from the aXcess Academy, various forums, mostly friendly folks.
You could interact across teams and build good networks as most of the people are welcoming.
cons:
Policies can differ from team to team and region wise or at least the FCC SPOT team followed different set of policies with regards to WFH, working hours, style.
No recognition for your work. Presented so many ideas for A3 challenge none was recognised due to dirty politics.
My Line Manager was horrible and inhumane always inflicting pain by deriding, taunting, ridiculing and being sardonic. Had not had such a bad manager ever in my career.

headline: It's good of you are in the right team
pros: Good friendly folks and the top management is very good. Lot of training and learning opportunities.
cons: HR team is the worst and I don't like the idea of all the powers concentrated on your line manager. There is no way to reach out to the HR or anyone else for that matter without your line manager's notice. And if you get a bad one or facing some issues with him or her it's just going to be a nightmare.company policies are no applicable to all teams. headline: Very ugly and unpleasant experience
pros: Central location and good access to food, but you'd be broke if you ate at Pavilion everyday.
cons: Favouritism, racism, group bullying behaviour, no cooperation, unprofessional. After a long painful process of hiring - my superior did not even remember my starting day. The team was 95% female, several were domineering unforgiving Alphas with daddy issues. In an open office set up, when agitated on the phone, they would speak loudly, be rude and let the whole floor listen to their power trip and rants. Very disruptive and not conducive environment. Favouritism was very clear, and the 99% females would be very obviously 'softer' on the younger males and ignore others. If you got into the group's bad books or said something they didn't like, you were marked. And they make it very clear. If they avoid you, good. But if they want to have 'fun' they will speak to each other in a different language about you, not behind your back but right in front of you, thinking you don't know how to read tone of voice and vibes. Not right. Basically, if they want you out, they will make it very unpleasant. To a point where it's worth your sanity and dignity to leave. No point in speaking up to HR when it's your own supervisor who's the cause of this attitude. It's a cold place if you don't behave like them. Do not be like them. No support from HR either. They're hard to get, unavailable, late in responding to emails or on leave. Be warned.

headline: Imbeciles Everywhere that are "Here for Good"
pros: Should you desire a career experience where you become less intelligent, be surrounded by idiots and imbeciles, and get invited for 200 tea/coffee breaks a day by people who do not do any work, then this company is here for you.
cons:
1) Too many imbeciles, lazy bosses and clueless colleagues who are "Here for Good". Their only purpose is to milk the bank of its cash while not doing any work. All they do is (a) Talk at meetings without making sense, (b) try to steal your work and pass it off as their own (c) push emails around to 'coordinate' and seem like they are doing work.

2) Which company has so many 'Head of XXX' and big inflated titles? I think SC has up to 75 CFOs and 30 COOs. One COO will manage 15 COOs...who in turn manage other COOs. (there's CIB COO, CFO COO, FM COO, FM Finacne COO, GB COO, GB ASA COO....etc etc) and this repeats for all the C-Suite functions. When these psudo C-Suite and peduso-Heads go out to market, they are laughed at. COO Salary at 1/20th the salary of a normal COO elsewhere? Have a laugh. They might have a Toilet CFO, Pantry CEO, Head of Meeting Rooms, MBFC Gantry CFO, ATM CFO, Email CFO etc. The common joke when someone is heading to SC is: "oh, what department are you heading?" - even for a fresh graduate.

3) Many Senior Managers/ Middle Management are clueless about their role. They managed to secure their position by jumping internally to various other roles. Where clueless managers (who do not know what is needed) hire such clueless staff; who in turn also hire other clueless staff. The entire pyramid is rotten - nobody knows what is going on. Managers throw around big words like "Big Data" and "Machine Learning" and "Unsupervised Learning" while not know what they really are. Do simple balance sheet calculations seriously need big data and unsupervised learning? It's simple accounting! Worst thing is that their bosses are impressed, and themselves go about throwing these words around - as if it will solve the bank's problems. No amount of ML can help you if you do not even have proper data - its like trying to build a skyscraper using tissue paper. I daresay the entire chain relies on the poor fresh graduate at the bottom who tries to properly understand what the job is about. 

4) Staff in Singapore from certain other countries are rude and demeaning to the auxiliary staff in office - such as the cleaners, concierge, building services. They place used cups in the pantry, especting the cleaner to wash it for them. They leave food around, expecting the cleaner to clean up after them. Worst of all, if you have ever had the misforunte of working at their Changi Business Park office, you'll realise that there are humans in need of toilet training like infant animals! They do their business anywhere but into the toilet bowl, and pee all over the place. It is so bad that the building services team has asked the cleaning uncle to clean up every hour! Every. Single. Hour. The poor cleaning uncle has a torrid time.

5) The bank's systems are archaic. Probably can't talk about it in specifity but you will realise you're better off with paper and pen.

6) Last but not least, there is no accountability. Ineptitude, sloth, slipshod work, and even malfeasance is tolerated throughout the bank. Managers who do not deliver projects after asking for millions of dollars of funding are still around; their projects conveniently forgotten and written off. What they do is to find a new role within the bank, and chuck the project off into some god-forsaken hole. Individuals seem to be graded on how many times they have coffee/tea with their managers instead of quality of work. If you've had the misfortune to grace the canteen in Changi Business Park during a work-week, you'll realise that it is constantly packed throughout the day with people having 'coffee chats' (which is really just a secret language for malingering).

--honestly, no consultant, system, way of working can fix the disaster that is Standard Chartered. It might be an option to liquidate the bank and start from bottom up again.

headline: Not good place for learning and not worthy to spend long term
pros:
1. 10 days block leave
2. Decent hike (but not all the teams)
cons:
1. Once you coming with good package then there won't be any hike for at least 2 years. You can get the answer 'You are already in the market'
2. No appreciation & awards. 
3. Managers/Senior managers i worked with them are non technical people. So you need to spoon feed them about what you have done. Make them to understand what you have done
4. Hike & promotion are not transparent. People who are in good touch with managers/senior managers get more as well as get promotion. There is no disclosure to team about the promoted people and there is no justification for promotion 
5. Recruiting automation resource and deploy them as manual resource and asked to extend work hours to do automation and they will give weightage for that too. It we are not meeting it then it will be impact on performance. They won't bother about work life balance even though company supported for that
6. Managers can do what they want, they are the authority to decide so raising voice against them doesn't help you. HR policies are just for name sake
7. If you have contacts inside the company you can get an offer. 
8. Internal vacancies are just for name sake, you won't get call for your application. It would be filled by known people. Most of the times, team decide the people and open the req
9. Your learning will be based on the team you are working and hike & promotion will be based on team. Don't just believe that it would be based on your performance. There is no value for performance
10. No hierarchy on team
11. You can see politics and can see more politicians. 
12. There won't any exit interview. So no even have last chance to spoke with HR.

headline: Join only if you have no alternative. Pathetic organisation.
pros: The brand name. That's all.
cons:
Yeah, you will get plenty here. 

1. Worst management, treats you as a slave.
2. Pay/Hikes/Appraisals way below market standard.
3. Inefficient managers (only has UG degree). No product/process knowledge and lack leadership quality.
4. HR has no play (other than hiring). Everything is managed by your line manager aka People Leader. So basically if you have any grievances you cannot take it up with anyone.
5. To be favourable you need to be a Tamil (or else regionally same as your manager)
6. Zero appreciation on performance (even if it's an acknowledgement over a call/meeting)
7. Leaves are sufficient (only if they let you take one other than block leave). This highly varies team to team.
8. Exceeding working hours (+ 2-3h) on a daily basis and not rewarded. 
9. Shift allowance policies are not up to the mark. 
10. Excessive cost cutting.
11. No transparency on policies from the organisation end. 
12. Conflict among team members which leads to loss of productivity and time.
 

All of these sumps up to no work life balance, excessive stress and health issues. And to curb all of it, even the pay is too less.

headline: Pathetic place to work, especially in India
pros: Organization provides the average benefits, nothing special.
cons: Where do I even start? The HR is non-existent, which means the managers run their respective teams like a fiefdom. Your Manager's word will be the gospel. The Global management changes every few years, so you will also see the strategy, organization design & management focus change every 3-4 years as well. Fact of the matter is, they have no bigger picture in their mind about what they want the bank to do, every incoming Global CEO will dictate his terms and reinvent the wheel every few years, and then the next CEO will come in & undo everything his predecessor did. For employees on the ground, this means that you're dispensable. Managers have little to no work. In fact, if you're a manager & a big enough sycophant, you can get by with doing nothing & just forwarding every single mail to your juniors and then blame them when things go wrong.

headline: Stable organisation with good benefits
pros:
1. Stability (there will be cost cutting across the year but generally, headcount is preserved as much as possible)
2. Good benefits (leave, flexi benefits etc.)
3. A generally forgiving culture 
4. Good and friendly colleagues
5. Most management folks (direct line up) are generally nice and open to feedback
6. Relatively good work life balance (depending on department and roles)
cons:
1. Some management staff will play the politics game
2. Too many acronyms, overlapping processes
3. Tend to launch initiatives, enhancements, roll-outs without them being perfected first and only to fix them later on which is troublesome and bring inconvenience to many
4. A lot of work has been outsourced, hence the chances of being made redundant has increased 
5. Consistent restructuring across the bank and reorganisation at top management makes things confusing and affects the ground staff to middle management (change is the only constant but you wouldn't want changes to occur so frequently without bringing any significant benefits)
6. If someone leaves, work is just distributed among the remaining folks. Nothing wrong until it stretches everyone to the maximum for long periods of time making it unsustainable 
7. If you make a mistake, management will always "blame" you and provide their views which are of hindsight. Views based on hindsight is something everyone can also say so you know what I mean

headline: Consider carefully before joining this bank
pros: The bank may look very attractive to a job seeker due to its name, and salary offered. There are generous HR policy and flexible work arrangement options.
cons:
If you are focused on self growth, especially in terms of skills and self value, please reconsider an offer from the bank. My observation while working in this bank is that it is very good at " retaining" people, so lots of people you work with can be very "experienced" people who have been "staying" for a very long time in the hope to climb corporate ladders and often got their wish fulfilled after many years of "hard labour". So if you are perseverant enough to stay with the bank for many years, you might end up in a similar situation, where you will be given a more senior title than the one given to you when you joined, and some increment to your salary, but then that's it. If human is the biggest asset to a bank, then this bank's asset is aging faster than average. and then you can imagine the future....


Lots of people in management positions ( at least those I met) are  not leaders but micro managers who gives detailed instructions on things that don't need it. They lack foresight or management skills of businesses and treat you as their means to achieve personal  KPI, rather than an asset to the bank who have a career to take care of too.

Lots of things that don't  make sense are instructed to be done , whereas lots of things that add value are ignored by managers.


there is not much technology being adapted, the way things are done are obsolete, which in a way protects those "very experienced " people. What they care about the most is respect and obiedience from you.

headline: Toxic work culture
pros:
Salary is good
Work from home option
cons:
The organization is highly understaffed and overworks the exiting staff to the levels of exploitation. 
The offer letter is wisely drafted. It states that the work hours are 9 hours, but one may have to extend given business need. People are working from 7 AM to midnight on a regular basis. 
The management brags that its staff works round the clock, fails to understand, no employee likes to work round the clock. 
The processes are not streamlined hence the employees are at constant stress and fear. 
There is an atmosphere of terror. 
People are highly bad behaved. 
Stakeholders treat you like bonded labour and talk to you in the most unparliamentary way, and still the HR cant do anything. In fact, the HR itself takes it from their stakeholders.

 In this company which is a much need. workplace is also good

This team has no values for experienced people (i.e the people who work for more than 5-8 years in the same team) they will not be given any big hike in salary.. No new projects will be given to them ... "Except for the people who the top management favours" also there will be events in the office campus but we won't be allowed to enjoy the event because our mangers will be there to chase us to do daily BAU... This is about only my former team. Other teams were much fun when we saw through our glass door view from the 2nd floor... I wish... I had been selected in that teams...!!

headline: The worst boss I ever had
pros: Family covered in hospitalization plan
cons:
My line manager was verbally abusive and has crossed lines more than once. Even when he apologized to me later, it meant nothing as this behavior would be repeated soon. 
Based on what I witnessed, he will not be verbally abusive if 1) you have a higher up that can defend you 2) come from a well-connected background 3) you can do something others can’t. Heard internally he has past abrasive relationships characterized by several loud arguments.
I have seen the same comments/work from me vs these people from 1 -3 that draw out polar opposite reactions from him. I can only conclude he does not know what he wants. In a proper western company, he would have been put in his place.

headline: Work Life Balance is a myth in this place
pros: There are unlimited medical benefits, that's it.
cons: Long list there. The place is extremely inhuman and is saddled with so many processes that no person, no matter how efficient, can ever put up with all of them. The Team lead position is only meant to be there for moral support, and they still manage to be inefficient at that too. The Credit Analysts are expected to do any and everything. Really long work hours, expectations to work on all the weekends, complete lack of guidance for new joiners, the list will go on & on. Recent policy changes being introduced include tracking every single mistake you make and then treating at as an excuse to lower your rating. They have introduced Dashboards to keep track of employee performance which has made the whole place a huge rat race.

headline: Review.
pros: The country teams are great - the environment in country is friendly, my own team is very supportive, flexibility allowed i.e. work from home, in country management is considerate, maternity leave is great, etc. The pay is good, learning opportunity is good up to a certain extent.
cons:
Unspoken corporate hierarchy/politics where your behavior is shaped based on the seniority of who you are addressing - one of the worst I’ve experienced though they advertise it as otherwise.

Blame game is big - focus should be “we found a problem what’s the solution” instead this ends up being a blame game instilling negativity and at times even fear.

Constant structural changes by higher management - and I mean constant with no clear rational or vision communicated to employees on ground facing these changes full face. These changes are sometimes blanket changes and seem like the are no considerations for particular regions/ countries. 

You spend a lot of time doing irrelevant work this may be due to being an international bank adhering to many international regulations but sometimes you feel you can drown in doing documentation work. A large part of this is because the bank supports “simplifying” this is not actually done. The bank invests heavily on software, etc to make the client experience smoother however internally there is much to do to simplify - there are so many systems created that do not speak to each other. Many times we have to deal with large data where we spend hours trying to clean it up as a result . Processes at times are slow because of so many unnecessary systems not speaking to each other and so many work flow layers - think of an assembly line for a factory each line assembling one thing (literally). Sometimes software and systems should be created to ease particular work - this is not done to the extent that you think that your stuck in the 90s with the way these processes has not yet been updated.

The big clients are everything and if you do one tiny mistake like not respond to them even if it’s way past working hours your questioned by everyone internally surprisingly the internal team will give you a harder time than the actual client itself. God forbid you make an error.



Some people at work need to learn communication skills.

Although I say that SCB encourages work life balance I have to add this does not apply to everyone - unfortunately some teams work constantly even on weekends and late into the night i.e. I do receive emails from those at 3 AM in the morning their time. And when asked they explain that they are under pressure and have lots of work to do. 

Many talented people were given the cut, this brings into an underlying question on job security always.

This is for maybe the bank management - management encourages speak up for all things and try to normalized it - however speak up to employees is the highest form of escalation and not very available option. Fear, worry, being questioned etc is always on the table.

A lot of teams frequently change and this change brings about inconsistency and confusion - i.e. every time this team changes they change along with it the way things are done e.g. team one prefers a, b and c. Team two comes and say go back
To 3,21 - then team 3 comes back and says no we should do a,b,c again.

Business team is the all knowing God for every known thing even the most irrelevant to them in the bank for some reason. They are like an octopus with arms extending everywhere and at the same time are definitely not empowered on relevant decisions because they are the con man for lack of better terminology.

headline: OPS
pros:
-Flexible and free working environment
As far as you can complete your daily task, management allows flexibility for working hour

-Willingness to let junior expressing opinions
Management will ask for opinions from junior staff, though sometime management just does not have a well understanding about the workflow nor system.
cons:
Terrible systems 
Really really a hell to operation staff. You can never imagine in Year 2019, an international financial institution is still using such terrible system. It is not a JOKE. The systems are much much worse than its major competitors like HSBC or Citi or DBS. Maybe the systems are little bit better than banks like Dah Sing bank or Bangkok bank in HK. 
To be fair, the middle or junior level managers know this issue.
Nevertheless, the overall strategy of the group is to spend the least to achieve the basic needs instead of spending little more to achieve normal level or even more.
As the result, when the market changes or clients demand more, they are reluctant to enhance the systems, instead, they ask operation to do more...even operation has already worked 10 hrs a day without any Overtime pay.  And this problem does not only happen in operation, it also happens in HR system, IT system etc.  Oh, anyway, the statistics is meaningless in the bank, because the management does not care you work 10 hr, 12hr or 24 hrs a day, the management just care if they can release back to home at sharp 18:00. You can hardly find a manager after 18:30 while the rest have to work from 9am to 8pm or even 11pm


So if you want to try systems two decades ago, it will be the best place for you!
So if you are seeking managerial level opening here, it will be a heaven to you!

headline: struggling and challenging environment, not the best option
pros:
- Benefits if able to use
- Time off policies 
- Generally nice people
cons:
- Too many  internal policies and processes don’t make sense and it’s clear that relevant teams had no input before role out and are still expected to bide by them. Sometimes it seems quite shocking if you’ve trained externally or have exposure at a market leader to see how backwards things can be as other companies don’t seem to function quite like this.
- Does not really value legal or regulatory compliance (ongoing large sanctions issues) and generally looks to short term gains to attempt to remain competitive. 
- Even in the instability as turnaround and cuts now don’t bring clear picture of how these are meant to help long term and little thought is and has been given to these in actual effect—there are just short term “wins” to appease shareholders.
- Has been declining for at least 5 years but now seems to really be failing and things are harder for those who haven’t been yet let go or left so serious need to think about plans.

headline: Standard Chartered Hong Kong
pros: The bank genuinely values staff's well-being. There is a lot of internal events, e.g. carnivals for staff to take part in. The medical welfare plan is also impeccable. Colleagues are generally nice. The Human Resources team is responsive and helpful so do reach out if you have any questions.
cons: From my own experience, the turnover rate is extremely high. A lot of staff members resign on a sour note. There is definitely a visible trend of 'title inflation' (might be attractive to some). The ratio of 'managers' to 'average staff members' within a team can hit as high as 50/50.  With that being said, the existence of mirco-management is an understatement.  For my team ONLY, the best way to  get a good rating for your performance appraisal appears to be 'getting into the squad' (definitely a workplace norm but they make no effort to hide it).

headline: Unstable with job cuts/low job security but friendly people and environment (2.5 stars)
pros: People are generally friendly and good environment. Interesting, fairly diverse and international and good work life balance and pto, good benefits
cons: Low job security and there are recent job cuts everywhere and constant restructurings affecting every department. Many contract employees and cost cuts/functions (and other signs) that show poor management and seemingly stagnant future. Not a major player so you kind of know what you're signing up for and get some work life balance but security issues make it lopsided in evaluating.  Consider this more seriously and honestly would probably only advise for someone in tight circumstances or maybe at entry level needing any kind of initial exposure. Pay is below market and 401K does not immediately vest. Potentially longer hours dealing with overseas.

headline: Work culture and Employee benefits
pros: Employee will sure get the comfort zone when they work for this company.  The banking institution is always the best place to explore a lot of things end to end. It has so many projects where the employee can gain knowledge into it.
cons: A lot of Management changes happens. It's not only the management Change but also the process model. When there was a new process model introduce by the time when employee get to settle down, there will be another change that took place. Where employee loses his opportunity on any process development as it would be moved or migrated. Lengthy process and still holds few manual processing.

headline: Run, don't walk away
pros:
Pay is above local banks 
Benefits are good including ability to encash part of the medical benefits, sell holiday days, access to cheap personal phone contracts, free tickets (subject to availability) for the zoo and night safari
cons:
None of the pros make up for the cons -

- Exceptionally political. 
- A lot of individuals not doing any work seem to survive thanks to a combination of sucking up to the boss and/or being from the same race and country (there is an Indian mafia, Pakistani mafia, Aussie mafia, British mafia and the only criteria for survival is to pick a team of the same nationality, any talent aside)
- a consequence of the nepotism is that there are a lot of unqualified resources who don't do much if anything and are still fairly safe despite any losses or failures 
- a lot of initiatives started with no hope of success and continue till it becomes so ridiculous that management pulls the plug. By this time, the MDs/ Ds and their cronies have gone through two bonus/promotion cycles and get an internal mobility out. The last patsy or the new one gets thrown under the bus. Rinse & Repeat. 
It's then somewhat surprising to see CEO and MT worry about why programs aren't generating returns. Surely you're all not that naive not to see that somee of your one and two downs are taking the bank for a ride. 
- Outsourcing to Chennai/ Bangalore/ Poland/ Tianjin may be cheaper but so badly done that processes still continue to sit in the original location while you now pay for high cost locations and low cost locations headcount.
Bear in mind that 75% of band 5, 6 and 7 resources fired doesn't mean that the remaining 25% will do 100% of the job while the low cost resources twiddles thumbs.

headline: The island of misfit toys
pros: The PTO policy is very generous; the benefits are affordable
cons:
The technology is the worst I've ever seen. Doing simple tasks like expense reports can be extremely time consuming simply due to the technology being so poor. Anything relating to admins is poorly funded and not well thought out. 

There is absolutely no training or proper onboarding for new hires. Completely ridiculous for a company of this size who uses a bunch of dumpsterfire programs that no other company uses. There is a very blatant "figure it out yourself" attitude. 

Admins here support WAY too many people. Could be 15, could be 20, could be more. The bank wastes tons of money on certain things but again, when it comes to admins, there is no consideration or investment. You're expected to essentially be on 24/7 call which is ridiculous for someone on the admin level.

The approval process for everything (for example: travel) is extremely convoluted. It seems that very few decisions (large or small) are made stateside- everything goes through Singapore or London which is a huge pain due to the time differences. Even band 3 employees in NY have absolutely no influence.

Bullying is a real problem and completely tolerated. No matter how many mandatory meetings this bank has about harassment and bullying, nothing will ever change because the most toxic people are promoted and never disciplined. Some of these managers and directors gossip more than what you would expect in a hair salon. HR is completely ineffective and lazy, the payroll department is equally incompetent. 

It seems like things may be better based on the reviews in some of the other SCB offices but the NYC office is a cesspool of incompetence.

This is not a place that attracts the best and brightest. A lot of people seem stuck here because they wouldn't get anywhere at any other bank.

The whole diversity thing is a farce. If you're not white, south asian or east asian good luck getting promoted. And speaking of promotion, when interviewing they tell you there are a lot of growth opportunities within the bank but generally this doesn't apply to most admins.

headline: Risk Management

The HR here is a joke and the company is insensitive to its own employees. After working and committing oneself to the bank, they will not even blink before cutting you off. Worst bank to work if you want job security. Highly recommended to find something other than stanchart, that you can pursue for long term. Also, the management is absolutely stupid, they make decisions before thinking of the consequences. Too much hiring and frequent change of processes is one of the most common features of the bank. This is obviously later justified by laying off people and cost cutting.

headline: Private Club
pros:
Technologies stack depends on team but new technologies are quite common, legacy things in process of elimination. 
More or less flexible schedule, modern software/computer/office. 
Decent salary. 
Whole bunch of talented people.
cons:
Processes management is worse than bad, it does not exist at all, no schedule, constant overtimes as consequence of poor planning, chaotic decisions without direction. Low working culture, no respect for private life, high pressure.

No diversity, most of people are from South India, technical discussions in Tamil are regular thing despite of some team members are not Tamil speakers. 

Very often people are hired not for their skills but for their loyalty / private connections.  Nepotism and lot of internal politics which affects performance and delivery.

headline: Not here for good!
pros: Flexible working, internal training, freebies, and some good colleagues.
cons: Quite a few malicious people encountered where bullying and favouritism is encouraged. Poor middle management layer who hold people back and make crap decisions resulting in poor business performance and no accountability.  Awful culture to the point good people just get fed up and leave.  No real recognition for the unsung heroes behind the scenes.  Budget cuts across the Bank from travel to resources is frustrating given senior management behaviour. Complex operating structure where key people are located on the other side of the world.   Pay and bonuses are well below market average.

headline: Dysfunctional and Frustrating
pros:
You can wallow in mediocrity and coast along without really effecting any change or process improvements.   Most people seem to.  Especially in Singapore.  

If you can land one of the inflated grade roles in London, especially in a back office, zero impact area, like HR, you can live a good life and travel a lot, whilst generating meaningful justification for meaningless projects.
cons:
No management support or strategic direction.  Any executive level plan is hampered by middle management agendas and personalities.  Some people only looking out for themselves to the detriment of employees.   

There is evidence of favouring contractors over employees to support personal agendas rather than doing the best for the company.  Resulting in lack of progress and increasing cost of (IT) operations.

headline: Credit Analyst
pros: Teammates are pretty nice and not as much politics within the team.
cons: CA job itself - long work hours, bad allocation of tasks, no control on work load since RMs can throw any task at you and say it is urgent, forced to do very admin work because IT system too stupid to do the admin work - never seen anything as admin as this and i hve worked at other banks before, no support from management at all. We are all left to drown in impossible workload and deadline. It is not uncommon to work over weekends / work late.  Zero work life balance and highly stressed life with low salary - not worth it. People only focus on your mistakes and not your achievements which makes the whole work experience highly demoralizing. Most people leave within 2 years or less. Hard work is not appreciated.

headline: amazing footprint but many legacy issues
pros: The bank has an amazing footprint.  If you want to work for a truly global, emerging market institution that can give you exposure to EM + Frontier, this is it.  They have deep history in many of these far-flung places and I would think they will never leave.  This gives a deeply embedded advantage over other international players and, of course, local competition.  I actually feel "here for good" is an excellent representation of this and a wonderful tagline for the company.  Long history, through it all, thick and thin.  If you stand in Central in HK and look at HSBC and SC buildings side by side (notwithstanding that SC sold its building a long time ago) you see what I mean - HSBC purportedly built its building to be modular so they could dismantle it and ship it out after the handover in '97 if things got hairy.  Who knows if this is true or not but the building looks the part.  SC building is a veritable fortress by comparison - in other words, "here for good" in living color.
cons: The bank has an absolutely toxic culture.  There has been far too much change at all levels of management.  New management come in, excited by all the aforementioned pros and have unreasonable expectations heaped on them and they simply cannot deliver.  The result is they fire their directs or themselves get fired (as the blame goes around) and the cycle repeats itself.  The bank has to figure out a way to break this cycle.  The people that have been around for more than 2 years are inevitably those that are best place to avoid getting caught by this - have either managed to fire and apportion blame or have avoided decisions or rose through the ranks quickly.  It's sadly apparent throughout the organization.  The functions are mediocre to incompetent and don't know how to support front office.  The middle and front of offices are working off of antiquated systems - there has been no investment in improving systems, majority of investment is on regs.  The conundrum faced by the institution is that so many areas of the bank need to be literally burnt down and rebuilt, but the cost to do so is so great, that it is simply not possible from the highest stakeholders (shareholders, board) on down.  Senior management rolled out a campaign recently, presumably to fulfill it's obligation to "change the culture" called "Our Shared Values."  In some ways it is good and necessary but in others it is a sad reflection on the state of the bank.  For instance, value #1 is "do the right thing."  In my opinion, anyone that is not clear on or doesn't automatically know to do the right thing shouldn't be at the bank to begin with.  So does this mean the bank tolerates employees or managers or don't spell out or do the right thing?  It's very confusing and illustrates the challenging place that the bank is in.

headline: a lower rating than one star isn't available
pros: Used to be a #Human place
cons:
Standard Chartered Bank has become utterly Orwellian strangled under the naif specter of operational risk and the organization revels blindly in all the inane toxic suffocating redundancies consequently created. 

The Human Resources (HR) function at Standard Chartered has always been disconnected from, and absolutely uninterested in anything to do with needs of the people there - its sole purpose remains to rubber stamp ever more disjointed "business call" and as always, filing out reams of doublespeak (jingoistic paperwork that never sees daylight). The hiring criterion has little do with the capability/track record/qualifications or cultural fit of a potential candidate - but rather is a factor of who is the 'cheapest' hire. 

At Standard Chartered PLC there is no succession planning/grooming. Pick a senior vacancy and they've mostly brought in an external candidate. This when the average tenure of the next-to-senior existing staff throughout the Group has not been less than 4 years. Not only does it reflect an obvious utter absence of investment in the 'talent' the organization already has, what this effectively also does is simple - it terminates the growth pipeline throughout the organization's considerable hierarchy. Internal international movements, much touted at job fairs, is the biggest fallacy at Standard Chartered - not only is grooming of existing staff absent, internal job advertisements are cursory, paper filling exercises - with absolutely no feedback on an application - even for the minority of vacancies where a candidate for the position hasn't already been pre short listed before the job is advertised. For "Group" level roles there is no active involvement in the hiring process of HR nor of the international mobility HR subfunction - nor is any hint given of the active xenophobic 'restrictions' to 'non native' hiring let alone any internal mechanisms to counter/mitigate it - but diversity is purportedly valued "highly" at Standard Chartered.  

At senior management level, these new hires have no inkling of the ground realities at the Bank, nor any interest in acquiring any modicum of understanding of the same - they each work off a set of preconceived notions that brook no contrary view - not that there are anymore forums where a different view to doing things could be aired or would be tolerated let alone invited. so no, you must not stay in your own house or with relatives while traveling for business, because the policy says you cannot and in any case there is no per diem - just pay the hundreds of dollars out of your own pocket (again as per policy - you lodge a claim once you return, and will be reimbursed some time in the future, only once the dozen forms, approvals et all plus the entire OR bureaucracy is sated) for a hotel room in which you barely will have time to sleep in. And good luck to you if for some reason the hotel didn't give you an original receipt/or you couldn't find it. Try getting the Bank to lend you money interest free for the time it takes to get your out of pocket expense money back. There is no forum nor interest anywhere in the Bank for you to try and simplify this - you cannot ask questions, for none are entertained - even though 'simplification' is the latest 'big' deal.

Much touted is "diversity and inclusion", which effectively amounts to touted quotas "enforced" for women with chauvinistic verbal homage tilted to putting up percentages and timelines - to replacing existing non vacant staff positions with women. Utterly no regard to the existing staff pool - because for the 'management' staff are redundant wood blocks. The active discrimination extends to gender exclusive (read women only) events (on which the Bank spends good money), gender exclusive (for women only) mentoring, gender exclusive face time with senior management. None such fanfare exists for existing staff who happen to not be female. At Standard Chartered there is absolutely not the least recognition/ space for any form of orientation diversity, safe work environment, let alone empowerment - the deliberate absolute silence on this could not be less gender phobic even if they tried! Conveniently to cover for their this bias they quote 'cultural sensitives of the markets they operate in' - yet oddly in these same markets they - purportedly - stringently enforce /zero tolerance of internal policies that forbid gratuitous token gift exchanges (a very cultural thing in 'their these markets') for example - at least there is a policy for this and a lot of blurb frequently circulated around it. That as opposed to the utter silence on orientation, safe work environment, tolerance et al.

The parallel organizational structures, much reviled by the current CEO when he joined, remain, with all the silos between the various businesses since re-enforced. The erstwhile "bridge" support functions were rendered neutered and headless at the start of his tenure, because they all had 'outsiders' appointed to 'lead' - who have little interest if any in the existing biology of the function/organization - reflected in the diktat that reign as the current "policies" there. So blase are these gents, one and all, that throughout the organization 'facts' no longer matter, 'appearances' are de rigueur - so intolerant of anything but their own view that their directs go to no uncertain lengths to ensure nothing filters up except what syncs with the "desired" state. Their titles increasingly grow remote, with the length /web of hierarchy under them expanding to the effect of leaving the totem pole so tall that even the middle branches are no longer visible (let alone accessible) from the ground.

Adopting the stance of the Group CEO are "regional CEOs" - who have little knowledge of, and even less interest in the "geographies" they "rule" - accordingly they grant arbitrary financial targets among their "dominion" and yet control not the spend of their court. They then hold their geographies to account for failing to 'deliver' for these same exorbitant uncured courtly expenses - which the regional CEOs have apportioned arbitrarily back to these same geographies. Courtesy the great 'purge' post the coming of Winter - a grim assemblage of reluctant yes men ekes out existence under increasing strangulation of self defeating policies while battling the redundant ogre of OR all the while waiting for the day to wind down so that they can clock out. 

Make no mistake this organization is NOT some 9to5 operation - long hours "at" work are expected (with frequent 'productivity' excel based  exercises) and the work phone given is guarantee that your attention will remain available whenever asked for. Need further proof? The vaunted 'refresh' of the 'core values' was the the hashtag #beingHuman, with an 'expected' set of "valued behaviors"! Orwellian huh?

headline: Business Banking Relationship Manager (Cash Team) - Singapore
pros: Apart of SCB's benefits which are excellent and competitive, there are NO benefits to this role at all. Things could be changing with a new Head (joined since approx 2015) who is actively seeking to revolutionize the department, but it takes time to pluck out the roots of a bad tree, so...
cons: The team is generally non-inclusive of other team members not in their clique, which speaks of the team lead's leadership. Processes are archaic, support is of no help, and job entails cumbersome paperwork. Although you may leave at 6pm, the paperwork is so overwhelming you will have to put in long hours anyways. Highly political environment, so much so that business is second place to self-preservation and protection of comfort zone. Had a team lead who was disrespectful to employees, and practiced favouritism. Workplace bullying is always not about physical abuse, or even overt verbal abuse but subtle emotional/mental abuse i.e. isolation, not regarding opinions and slighting them, etc.  IF you are reading this in 2018 - 2019 chances are the team lead here hasn't changed. So good luck.

headline: Unprofessional culture & bullying work environment
pros: Known international financial services brand
cons: Behind all the fancy slogans and brand name, SCB Kenya is a disgrace to the global brand and reputation of this financial services company. SCB encourages an extremely rude and demoralizing style of management especially in retail banking. Workplace bullying is commonplace.  Speak to the relationship managers and you will be told about repeated incidents and patterns of behavior intended to intimidate, offend, degrade or humiliate colleagues, all in the guise of bringing in clients and increasing "numbers'. It is an extremely unprofessional culture and a shame to SCB globally. Colleagues come to work and are demoralized because of the verbal abuse suffered at the hands of managers and heads of retail. This bank should be investigated.

headline: Worst Retail Banking to Work For
pros:
Nothing Significant worth mentioning. Horrible place to work. Don’t be fooled by the tag of a Multinational bank.
This bank is only surviving because of other Multinational companies (Unilever, Nestle, Telenor, UN) who must bank only with Multinational banks operating in Bangladesh and because of it’s employee banking.
cons:
1) Poor HR structure and compensation- no salary increment for years
2) Unfair to employee reimbursement- pay transportation, Courrier charges and phone bill from your pocket
3) Inferior Products - Impossible to sell (low deposit rates compared to competitors
4) Inhumane workloads
5) Unreasonable targets
6) Super bureaucratic
7) Zero team work and support from other departments
8) Lacks qualified Management
9) Harasses employees who tries to switch by delaying exit pack, putting them in investigation, delaying release letter, calling up other Organisations and bad mouthing the employee.
10) Zero alignment between retail department
11) Horrible work life balance (10 to 11)
12) Doesn’t reimburse you for working on weekends
13) Incentivises and it’s payout designed to ensure everyone fails to achieve.
14) 2 months notice period for resignation

pros: Nice and friendly colleagues
cons:
Organization undergoing major changes with no clear plan. They change their organisation structure twice a year. Very difficult to make progress on anything.
The business is doing very poorly, the organisation is struggling to cope with basic processes and has no resources to invest.
Lacks technical individuals in key functions, very unlikely to learn best practice from your colleagues, no budget to attract talent or train employees. Very hierarchical, most senior managers are veterans with the company, but in general outdated.

headline: IT Business Analyst

headline: constant rebranding?

Backstabbing , which was virtually non-exitent in this organisation, is  on the rise.

headline: Wouldn't Recommend
pros:
* Good Benefits-25 Days Vacation with the option for additional days depending on the number of children that you may have (2-6 days)
* Pay is relatively competitive
cons:
* Culture is very boss dependent but is generally quite cut-throat. In my case, I had a really difficult and unreasonable boss
* HR seems to take the side of line managers rather than attempt to fairly mediate in employee issues, there is no proper exit interviews for leavers as the HR function has been mainly outsourced to India
* IT systems are quite outdated and there is lots of manual work. IT enhancement projects are always behind schedule due to lack of resources and manpower allocated

headline: Structured
pros:
- Systems run purely on policy. There are no side shows or grey areas. 
- The company has good structured and a huge network of experienced people who provide mentor-ship. 
- Good on-job training provided on a continuous basis. 
- HiPo (High performing staff) are identified and the company works to retain them.  
- Fantastic benefits.
- Strong value system.
cons:
- Heavy workload in operations functions. 
- Too highly specialized. One might miss an opportunity to broaden their scope if not on a management trainee who get the opportunity to move around the organization. 
- Salaries for those who have grown in the system might be lower compared to peers in the market.

headline: First year really hard, can be frustrating, needs a lot of patience and then there is rewarding payoff
pros: Great for Asia time zone working (no late night calls with us/eu). Great people can have an impact if able to influence. Very diverse, you gain lots of insight from varied parts of the footprint, definite wind of change from 2016 onwards where you can see the cob webs being blown away (it takes time and patience though). Not that many big ego's - people generally on the level (this can be misconstrued as apathy sometimes)
cons: You need patience. It can be very frustrating to navigate and leverage to get things done. Don't expect spoon feeding, it's a "figure it out yourself" environment. Generally, office facilities are quite poor in some locations. Quality of staff is less developed countries causes frustration and leads to focus on rigid process (as people can't be trusted to think for themselves). Still some old guard clinging to power structures which creates some cliques (these are barriers to change and personal growth), HR is very weak - you are at the mercy of line manager for career development so must take into your own hands.

headline: There are worst places to work as a technologist
pros: If you are an unambitious person that just want some salary, this could be the place for you.
cons:
Your experience might vary according to the team you are in, but most technology teams are uninspiring and spend more time talking than doing. 
Management has a sharp eye to detect employee entitlement but is completely oblivious to corporate and their sense of entitlement.
They expect intrinsic motivation from employees, despite all the actions the company takes to demotivate people.
Make sure to negotiate hard before signing the contract, in special if you are relocating to Singapore. Do not expect any salary increases or promotions for technical work, playing politics is essential.

pros: There are none, oh hold on, yes great coffee shop!

My face did not fit from day one and was Ignored by most in the team that I worked directly for. I would try and generate conversation but was basically ignored or had one word answers. I was also was shouted at across an open plan office on several occasions which not only degraded me in front of others I was totally humiliated, TOTALLY unprofessional. I went to the HR person but nothing was done and I all I wanted was a transfer elsewhere. WORST working experience of my life

2) Reward people who are loud and rude to anyone who is of lower rank to them
3) Senior managers only care how they present themselves in front of the big boss and not their own staff.
4) Tick box control culture, not focus on real risk items.

headline: Don't join unless you are in your 40's
pros:
25 Days Annual leave. The leave benefits are wow. Senior managements goes on holiday every month. The 20 weeks long maternity leave is unheard of in Singapore as well. But don't be fooled by these. 

If you are well into your late 30's or 40's with family commitments and looking for work-life balance, this place will be perfect for you.
cons:
Redundant middle-senior executives. Very obsolete IT system (you wouldn't believe it).  I know of a guy who didn't receive his work laptop for close to a month and he quitted because there's nothing he could do at work. For design and IT professionals, if you are driven and young and ambitious, don't come here. You won't learn much. 

Management don't appreciate development teams. They have been around for ages and does not contribute much to innovation. Innovation and user experience becomes lip service, buzzwords. Hire the right talents from other fields and not legacies from other banks.

headline: Superb culture
pros: Standard Chartered Bank (SCB) has a superb culture that attracts talented people from diverse backgrounds. Compared to many other leading international banks, SCB encourages its employees to have a good work/life balance, and offers employees volunteering days to support charitable causes.
cons:
There are limited career growth prospects, especially for employees who are not based in the bank's key footprint markets, Africa, Asia and the Middle East. 

At times, the number of approvals required to conduct business can take several months, thus making the whole process of executing deals incredibly frustrating.

headline: Good pay but lots of hierarchy and politics between teams
pros: Good compensation and bonus if team performs well (about 10-20% below bulge bracket)
cons:
Many MDs with overlapping coverage and hence quite a political organisation
Compensation can vary widely across teams even for people in the same rank - initial negotiation is quite important
Been alot of restructuring the past few years -

headline: Dysfunctional and lurching from crisis to crisis
pros: Good perks - free and cheap tickets to concerts, drinks in the office on Fridays. Some opportunities to travel to other markets (depends on your line manager - some are keener on travel than others), good commitment to flexible working (again, depending on manager). Highly multicultural and international, which makes the work often interesting.
cons:
Very long working hours (on email from 6am to 10pm, in office from 7.30am to 7pm, frequently later, on occasions until 3am). Resourcing gaps rarely filled - when half the team went on maternity leave, the rest of us were given double workloads as "stretching objectives" only to be passed over for bonuses and promotions. 

Poor management culture; decisions and progression based on who you know and are friends with rather than skill or experience. Management don't value subject matter expertise. Extremely low morale; many jobs were cut, others walked at the same time. People left are those who can't leave because of visas, or who simply can't get another job.

Frustratingly bad IT. Clunky old kit, limited access to any online tools that would make the job easier. Made a big song and dance about a new intranet but it seems the same as the old one only with more corporate banner ads. Takes days to get basic IT or HR problems fixed.

headline: was alright

cons: The recent switch  and changes to management structure and style is a issue as with many other companies, it makes for a lot of uncertainties and employees feel unappreciated for many years of service, career growth within is hard to come by as it seems who you are connected to is considered more than your ability to perform the role .

headline: Here for good?
pros: It's a large bank with offices around the world. If you make the effort, there's a great learning opportunity here from the sheer diversity of the employees and the markets in which the bank operates.
cons:
No job security....several redundancies since 2012 and continuing....with nothing being done to lift the morale and culture of those that remain. Poorly managed.

Zero work-life balance. Sadly, in some offices it is still considered admirable if employees put in uselessly long hours...regardless of the quality of their output!  It's the 21st century but this archaic culture is deeply embedded.  

Looking in from the outside, their overall corporate strategy seems to be undecided at best.

headline: Comfortable environment, complicated processes, management VERY-RESULTS driven
pros:
Firstly,The people. Generally, a bank with very welcoming and open working culture. Flexible, reasonable and understanding in general. 

Secondly, the benefits. Think their benefits are really hard to beat. A good source of motivation. 

Welfare. Very good arrangements and staff welfare in general.
cons:
The extremely complicated hierarchy. The incompatibility of many different systems that don't talk to each other. Processes can be long, arduous and time-wasting. 

Management. Too focus-ed on wnd results or big picture. Tendency to neglect the situation on the ground, where it really matters or where help is really needed. High turnover rate - too concerned with cost management (hiring people) at the cost of losing valuable assets - having their best people poached by other companies.

headline: FCC
pros:
SCB is the only bank that provides the best benefits and welfare to staff. 
Teamwork prevalent depending on departments 
SCB seems more international at regional or group function. Support provided from team members are mostly available. Touch points are easier to be reached. 
Code of conduct has become the focus. Good direction.
cons:
Setup of new departments often hired externals. 
Externals do not understand SCB culture well and result in a lot of misunderstanding and tension.
Projects which were pre-planned and executed halfway could be call off with no available notice. Members work hard and feel depressed the meaning of those projects once established.
 Bullying and scolding are very common by managers in this bank,specially fcc functions. Members hesitated to escalate such inappropriate behaviours though the bank's portal. Kindly look into these issues. 
Technology is really back dated. Staff still using excel 2007 or 2009. Other banks are using excel 2013. Are we making things easier for staff to perform better at work?

headline: (in)famous in Electronic Trading
pros:
SCB has a great footprint.  It is a global company in just about every emerging market.
There are a number of good people at SCB.
SCB pays above the market average, though it became instantly clear the inflated rates are "danger money".
Morale is ok in pockets, sadly not in my business area (eComs)
There is a lot of genuinely funny trench-humour with laughter at the seemingly duplicitous and machiavellian behaviours of business and technology leadership.
cons:
The attrition within Standard Chartered is the highest I have seen.  It is like a revolving door across the business and technology team with many complaining about the same root cause.  
IT heavily micro-managed by the business using their historic and out-of-date knowledge, this heavily impacted courage, creativity and agility.  
Projects start with brutality and no regard for personal circumstances.  Demands for immediate business travel are not unknown which made the eTrading the least family friendly environment I have experienced.
Infamy of certain business heads impact seriously on hiring, hence the need to over pay for "hero work"
Name calling, rudeness and arrogance purveyed by business heads led to a wider trust issues within the global team. 
I saw many simply give up because of the risk of upsetting certain business heads.  This was a shame as it suppressed intelligent thinking.  
Being part of a clique essential to longevity.

headline: Financial analyst

cons: Terrible management. COO got transferred. Director to COO was forced resignation. Too many office politics. 80 hour work week.

headline: Great environment but lacks individual mobility

headline: Telemarketer
pros:
Nice colleagues
Supports education advancements
Uses auto dialer system therefore there's no need for manual dials
Good medical benefits
cons:
Commission comes in quarterly basis, and if you do not hit the target basically you go home empty handed for 3 months.

Phone calls are check by "quality assurance" which is unreasonable as they expect to hear all information conveyed to customers in ONE call. Even if customer insists on hanging up the phone.

ZERO authority to follow up with your own customers after they sent in their application, therefore causing huge delays and high complain rates. (No outbound calls, no access to emails)

Slow processing of "fulfillment team" sometimes even cause your cases to be "purged"- case is not retrievable despite receiving customer's applications.

Management micro manages.
Lunch break officially starts at 1300 and ends at 1400 sharp, if you're on the phone with customer and only hung up at 1345, you're only left with 15 minutes. Late comer for lunches will be given warnings.

Requested to work on weekends and OT with no pay.

headline: Good Company Depending On Location.

cons: Depending on the country and location of the company, the culture varies from being very good and cooperative to downright bad. Politics is rampant and the main driving force in the company, especially the work life balance culture can be sometimes preposterous. Movement and promotion within company is very restricted and mainly depends on who you know and how you maintain your relationship with him/her. Some of the heads openly misbehave with its employees, and sometimes can call you in abnormal hour of the day even if you are sick or on leave.

cons:

headline: Compliance
pros: Big presence in Asia. Big pantry for staff and lots of space to mingle. Free cups with company logo for all to use.
cons:
Always restructuring and changing processes. By the time staff fully grasp the latest changes, another wave of change begins again. 

Flexi working arrangement that result in inadequate workstations and chairs. Working from home is still not widely practised hence staff still come to office. Some start to fight over tables, chairs, lockers or pedestals. Why can't the bank provide adequate basic resources for everyone? It's ridiculous. 

Toxic management who only care about protecting their rice bowls. There are senior management who push blame to others and keep scolding and shouting at people openly, creating a very negative working environment. There is no respect for staff.

headline: Indian Dominated Regional and Country Management
pros:
1. Good compensation! Can get higher than market pay.  
2. Provide good training.
3. Anyone can change to any roles internally.
cons:
1. Very political. Especially obvious after restructuring exercise. The regional and country management filled by almost Indian. Diversity and inclusion is out of the picture. Worst of all, some of them are incompetent to lead compare to those before the restructuring exercise. Toxic culture created and employee moral and motivation dropped. Most of the good employee already left. 

2. A bank that only doing good on digital banking. The rest of the IT applications are obsoleted. Obsoleted also never mind, enhancement process is taking very long. Not agile at all! Whenever want to do a system enhancement, the "Scope International" will charge unreasonable high fees. So, to save cost, the operation is expanding organically. They are building an army behind the system to do manual works (Adding a headcount is cheaper than system enhancement). Come on, this is a serious strategic issues!

cons:
Too many changes, too often means employees feel defensive about their jobs (beuracracy).
Instability and attrition results to disruption from lost talent from staff leaving and low productivity. 
Selfish managers.

headline: Big ambitions but lack support

Big on charity and community initiatives
Payscale between 1st tier and Chinese banks
Global bank with opportunity to work aside staff in multiple locations
cons:
Lack of supporting staff, but nonetheless have very high expectations on research quantity Increasingly outsourcing support staff offshore which cannot deliver similar quality of work
Aggressive in replacing staff during the current investment bank down-cycle, no job security

headline: Sales and service manager
pros: Right place to work,my first job is with scb and my last job with scb.currently searching job with scb
cons: Promotion ratio is very low

headline: Toxic - no longer a meritocracy
pros: Apparent culture and all the charities supported when I joined which have sadly seen huge cuts.
cons:
The new management had to cut - sadly it is no longer a meritocracy and many good people who made money for the bank were let go as the cuts trickled down and senior managers protected allies.
The best people are moving to other banks leaving a sub optimal standard, in my opinion the bank is ill equipped to meet the challenges it faces.
The impact on the culture has been huge with many good people managers gone it has encouraged a much less collegiate work place.  Those who remain say morale is at an all time low.

headline: Disastrous
pros: International firm, that's all the Pro I can think of.
cons: Pretty much everything that you could think of, from the companies' structure, policies, to your colleagues and salary.  I am not a whiner but this is the impression I get after working for a year in this company.  I have worked in four different banks, overseas and Hong Kong and I have to say this company is by far the worst I have worked in.  Zero sense of belonging pretty much explains why the turnover rate is consistently high here, you are already considered to be a senior staff here if you have worked for two years as not a lot would make it over two years.

headline: Ex long term employee review
pros: Employee benefits were adequate but not the best. Health benefits for dependants were included but every bank has that.
cons:
Bank is in a mess. They take advantage of long term employees and are incapable of keeping talent due to weak middle management which translates to an awful
culture of rewarding mediocre people and performance.

headline: Relationship manager retail bank woes
pros: Good HIPS programme for medical, insurance benefits; shares vesting programme, comprehensive and rigourous training academy for wealth management joiners.
cons: Top management are more interested in politics and power consolidation rather than walking the ground. Middle management are interested in impression management and keeping their jobs by squeezing ground people dry, sending them to daily late night calls or roadshows till 9pm and threaten to put them on PIP program unless you get clients to do risky high revenue points generating products. Disregard for industry best practices on wealth management concepts and just want to slaughter the golden goose for eggs. Extremely negative experience. Most (80%)resign due to long hours and moral hazard issues within 3 years.

headline: Poor Management, now feeling the effects
pros: Good chance to work in Asia if that's what you are looking for. A few years ago they had a very good relocation package, not sure if that is still the case. Negotiate a good salary when you join as very few of my colleagues received pay increases while I was there.
cons:
Now feeling the effects from years of promoting poor quality managers to positions where they are out of their depth and have become a hindrance to getting the job done. In IT you are just a body to be assigned to whichever project your line manager chooses, your own career progression goals are ignored. The IT PMs seemed to think that having daily status meetings (sometimes even twice a day) and calling them scrum meant they were 'doing agile'....

Changi business park office contains lots of dead wood completely detached from the front line. Visit the canteen at any time of day and you'll find people playing pool, having coffees and generally slacking off. Management need to get a grip and improve productivity.

headline: An old Bank that needs a new perspective

cons: Too many silos and bureacracy. Very slow decision making process, and hardly any career growth opportunities.

headline: Standard Chartered Bank
pros: good platform, large client base, comprehensive exposure
cons: bad pay, complicated internal setup, tough sales target

headline: Go in with your eyes open
pros: I was paid fairly, bonuses were fair, decent opportunities for learning and growth.  I had really good work-life balance, although some colleagues did not.  I was allowed and expected to control  my own balance.  As long as the work got done, I had a great deal of freedom.  That was nice.  Standard Chartered is in a lot of very interesting and challenging markets.  It was never boring.
cons: Execution is a challenge.  Systems are antiquated and generally updated in a hodge-podge manner.  Standard Chartered Bank acutally operates as a federation of local banks and that needs to change desperately.  "The right hand does not know what the left hand is doing."  Way too many layers of management - though I think that is starting to change finally.

headline: Not Ready for Investment Banking
pros: Global footprint with core focus on Asia, Africa and the Middle East; strong brand (and willingness to put balance sheet to work) in emerging markets
cons:
Standard Charted talks a good game (internally and externally) about wanting to be a competitor in the traditional investment banking businesses (securities underwriting, equities, bonds, M&A advisory), but while I was there the bank proved again and again that it is, at its core, a lending and trade finance bank with at best limited appetite to (i) take the organizational and strategic steps and (ii) hire & compensate the people necessary to compete even on a regional basis.

(Glassdoor won't let me use a sufficiently general location, but I was based in North America.)
